entry.title: Hypothesis Testing
entry.answer:
We want to test the hypothesis that the drug has no effect. In this case our hypothesis is $\mu_0=0$, the mean of the differences is unchanged. Our alternative hypothesis is $\mu_0 > 0$. This is a *one-sided* test, since we do not test whether the drug potentially reduces the IQ of the participants.
We can calculate the $t$-statistic as \begin{align*} t_{\rm obs} = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu_0}{s/\sqrt{n}} = 3.68, \end{align*} since $\bar{x}=2.33, \mu_0=0, s^2=4.0, n=10$.
If $H_0$ is true, then the probability of observing this value of $t(\vec{X})$ is \begin{align*} p &= \Pr( t(\vec{X}) \ge 3.68) \\ &= \Pr(t_9 \ge 3.68) \\ &= 0.0025. \end{align*} This means that, if $H_0$ is true, then we would see this result about $0.25\%$ of the time, that is, an extremely rare event. Under these conditions we would reject the null hypothesis.
